Award.AwardTitle: Impacts of polyandry and mate limitation on female fecundity and the population dynamics of the aspen leaf miner
Award.AbstractNarration:
Populations of some species can persist at low numbers for long periods of time and then quickly rise to very high numbers. When these species inflict damage on human resources, their population "explosions" become a practical concern. It is often difficult to study populations when they are very small because individuals are so rare and hard to find. Yet, understanding what keeps a species rare and what happens to shift populations into periods of rapid growth is important for predicting and controlling outbreaks of many kinds. This research examines possible reasons for dramatic cycles of abundance in the aspen leaf miner, a tiny species of moth that is usually rare but can outbreak and cause extensive damage to aspen trees. In particular, investigators will test whether females in small populations are unable to mate as often and lay as many eggs as females in large populations. If confirmed, low mating success in small populations may be important in controlling other forest pests and slowing the spread of invasive species.

Due to its high level of polyandry and sustained low and high population phases, the aspen leaf miner (Phyllocnistis populiella) feeding on quaking aspen (Populus tremuloides) provides an excellent system for exploring potential demographic impacts of mate-finding Allee effects on large amplitude population fluctuations. This project will use a combination of experimental and observational approaches to address whether mate-finding Allee effects and polyandry contribute to sustaining low phases of the aspen leaf miner. Specifically it will employ: 1) mating experiments to examine whether multiple mating increases female fecundity, and 2) observational studies across populations with varying densities to address whether potential and realized polyandry increases with population density. A better understanding of the mechanisms keeping populations at low density or releasing them into growth phases will aid predictions of where and when outbreaks are likely to occur.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Populations of some species can persist at low numbers for long periods of time but then quickly rise to very high numbers. When these species inflict damage on human resources, the causes of changes in population size become a practical concern. It is often difficult to study populations when they are at low numbers, yet understanding what keeps them low and what happens to shift them into periods of population growth is important for predicting and controlling population outbreaks. This research examined possible factors contributing to the maintenance of low population numbers of the aspen leaf miner (Phyllocnistis populiella), a tiny species of moth that often occurs at low population size but can outbreak and cause extensive damage to quaking aspen trees (Populus tremuloides) (Fig. 1).

 

The aspen leaf miner has caused large outbreaks in extensive areas of Alaska and the Yukon Territories over the last two decades (Figs. 2 and 3). Female aspen leaf miners mate multiple times and almost certainly obtain not only sperm but also nutrients from each mating. These nutrients may then allow the female to produce more eggs over her lifetime. This research examined whether at low population size, mating success is reduced leading to fewer eggs laid by each female moth. Low mating success at low population numbers may be important in controlling other forest pests in addition to the aspen leaf miner, and slowing the spread of invasive species. Therefore understanding the potential of low population size to impact mating success and egg production may help in the control of a variety of pest species.

 

This research grant provided proof of concept funding to examine the feasibility of two lines of research: 1) mating experiments to examine whether multiple mating increases female fecundity; and 2) observational studies across populations with varying densities to address whether potential and realized polyandry increases with population density.

 

To address our first goal, we succeeded in collecting virgin female moths when they first emerge from overwintering sites in the leaf litter beneath white spruce trees and then establishing mating pairs under artificial conditions. However, while moths readily mated under experimental conditions, it proved very difficult to find conditions under which they would lay their eggs. We conducted these trials over three years (2016-2018) are tried a variety of containers for housing the moths and environmental conditions, but none of these led to females reliably laying their eggs.

 

To address our second goal, in the spring of 2016 we established 17 new field sites spanning a range of aspen leaf miner density. We used sticky traps to monitor moth density throughout the mating and egg laying period. We then dissected females moths collected in sticky traps to determine the number of times each had mated. From these data we could examine the relationship between moth density and the average number of times that females mated. In 2017 this research was repeated at 10 of the sites. We found that female mating frequency increased with adult moth density.

 

This proof of concept research established our ability to monitor adult aspen leaf miner density across sites of variable density and to determine female mating frequency. It further confirmed that female mating frequency increases with population density, suggesting that mating success may be important in driving changes in population size and the initiation of outbreaks. We were unable to design conditions that led to reliable egg laying in captive moths, and, at this time, are unable to determine the relationship between female mating frequency and total eggs laid.

 

This research also contributed to training of 1 high school student, 4 undergraduate students, and one Master’s student. All received training in field and/or laboratory research techniques. Some were also trained in data management and analysis.
